Sure, here are a few fun activities that may cater to auditory learners:

1. Podcast discussions: Assign your students to listen to a podcast or an audiobook related to the current topic at hand. They can discuss and debate the topic in class. 2. Music-based learning: Use music to teach and memorize information. You can create songs and chants for theme or vocabulary memorization. 3. Debate and argumentation: This activity involves students presenting their arguments, facts, and opinions to their peers. Students can improve their critical thinking, speaking and listening skills, while auditory learners can listen to and analyze their peers' arguments. 4. Storytelling: Encourage your students to create, tell or retell stories. This activity improves their vocabulary, presentation skills and encourages creative thinking. Storytelling can be done individually, in pairs or as a group activity. 5. Role-playing: In-role playing, students can act out and play different parts in role-play scenarios such as historical events or current events. To make it more exciting, they can create scripts, sound effects, and background music. 6. Audio-recording: Encourage students to record themselves reading or presenting a book, a speech, or a presentation. They can listen to themselves and self-evaluate their presentation skills. Remember, it's all about making learning fun and interactive. Introducing activities that cater to auditory learners will make them feel engaged and motivated to learn.
